replies.author: @MK-jc6us
replies.text:
‚Äã@StrayChoom Lenin was not a Menshevik, he didn't say that capitalism (state capitalism or not) was necessary as a prior step to advanced socialism. Chinese authorities say today that capitalism is necessary as they first need to create wealth and raise the well being of the people in very broad terms. Lenin had a very different outlook, he said that State Capitalism should be a tactical retreat, and a short-lived one. The Chinese rule does not even has a roadmap to their transition to socialism, because it will never come.
Lenin's NEP had 2 main reasons: 1- Food. The peasants needed immediate incentives to produce and trade grain. 2- Investment / know how. Communists made the revolution but were basically ignorant about how to deal with practical things and they lacked machinery. Unfortunately they failed and didn't learn despite some success in getting foreign investment. The Chinese had much more time to learn, I wonder when they will start to move away from capitalism (never I guess).
State Capitalism was a tool in a basic and initial form of primitive Socialism, Soviet Union was socialist as the political power was in the hands of the Soviets/Communist Party, a State Capitalism without Socialism would be useless for the Soviet Union. Read again the part where Lenin says that it is thanks to the Soviet political power that they are able to make a step back (not really back as capitalism in Imperial Russia was primitive - but we understand what Lenin meant).  So of course it was already socialism, but one in its infancy. Again, hard to tell when Chinese "socialism" will move away from his "tactical" retreat from the market economy with Chinese characteristics (whatever this is supposed to mean but for sure we will find a lot of orientalist and eloquent explanations on that).

replies.author: @sihplak
replies.text:
@alexjeffrey3981 Section 7 of the party constitution, accessible on the ACP website (you can navigate to it via the Party Program page, then go to the "Constitution" section of the header on that page):

"Section 7:
Discrimination according to race, ethnicity, sex, or religious creed is strictly prohibited. To offend, demean or degrade the heritage of a given historically-constituted group is strictly prohibited. Any violation of the dignity and privacy of a given Party member on the basis of sex or other characteristics is strictly prohibited."

One thing I'll add; some people criticize it for it not explicitly referring to gender, but there are two points to contend against that: for one, the wording includes "other characteristics" and protects the dignity and privacy of party members very explicitly, and there are gender non-conforming members of the party. The second point is that, if individuals dislike this aspect of the constitution, the ACP as a party is open to critique, dialogue, and development, so should the party democratically decide that the wording should be more specific in its future meetings that can change.

Or, to put it another way; if you are authentically a Communist, but you have criticisms about aspects of the party, you can still join the party and voice those concerns or issues and potentially see that change be realized. The ACP does not dogmatically stick behind the ideas of any individual, even those of Haz.

author: @paulussturm6572
text: I have my own disagreement with the ACP, chiefly on the colonial question. I have also personally witnessed many of its members act like absolute reactionary sc*m online. Now, regarding the second flaw, I recognize that it's not a matter of party theory, that it's p much likely to be expected when you're trying to get people to leave the far right, and I also need to mention that in most of these instances they were soon criticized by other people who identify with the ACP. The first issue is much deeper and I basically cannot in good faith call myself a supporter because of it, seeing as it is not the fault of individuals within the party but its theoretical standpoint that is the problem on that one for me. So I'll criticize the party on that one. But I really don't get why so many of your critics feel the need to twist your positions by appealing to preconceived notions mostly manufactured by online drama (albeit, that one's also kinda on the online-provocateur strategy of your party, partly) while doing so in a way which only betrays their pedestrian understanding of politics. I'll also applaud the fact that the party is developing and strictly holding to a precisely outlined theoretical curriculum for its members, even if I've my own critiques of it.

we are fighting for communism to lighten the load of women, among many other things. so that women that ARE natural leaders [i personally don't believe this is as much of an anomaly as slava seems to think] can take up the mantel without having to worry about who is going to take care of the kids, put food on the table, etc.

yes, the goal is for women to have equal representation. but there are MANY obstacles put in place by the capitalist system that make it very difficult. which is just one reason, among many, that the acp is working toward a proletarian revolution.
